channel.title: BBC News - Europe

item.title: Turkey fires: Blazes threaten Marmaris and other coastal resorts
item.description: Villages and hotels are evacuated as firefighters attempt to put out dozens of blazes.

item.title: Amazon hit with $886m fine for alleged data law breach
item.description: The tech giant rejects claims it has broken European Union data protection laws.

item.title: Russia stops Cubans trying to enter EU on air beds
item.description: Three Cubans caught trying to cross a river into Estonia are said to have been heading for Spain.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Georgia athletes removed from Games after sightseeing trip
item.description: Two Georgian silver medallists are told to leave the Olympic Games for taking a sightseeing trip in Tokyo.

item.title: Eurozone out of recession after economy grows 2%
item.description: Data suggests all economies in the 19-country bloc expanded in the last three months.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Russians face backlash from fellow competitors
item.description: The Russian Olympic Committee are fourth in the medal table at the Tokyo Games but their athletes are facing questions from fellow competitors about whether they should even be there.

item.title: Euro 2020: Wembley steward admits theft over Euro final wristbands
item.description: Yusaf Amin tried to sell security passes, uniforms and wristbands to ticketless fans for Â£4,500.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Remains confirmed as those of missing hiker
item.description: Esther Dingley disappeared in the Pyrenees mountains in November.

item.title: Mitholz - the tranquil Swiss village facing a time bomb
item.description: More than 60 years after a deadly explosion ruined Mitholz, the village remains under threat.

item.title: The fungus and bacteria tackling plastic waste
item.description: Bacteria, fungus and enzymes can all digest plastic, but can they work at a useful commercial scale?

item.title: Covid: Stalled Russian vaccines cause global anger
item.description: Deliveries of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine have fallen far below expectations.

item.title: Dressage: How to make a horse dance
item.description: For some, it's an oddity to watch only at the Olympics... for others, it's a lifetime of training.

item.title: Roma child: 'My only goal is to finish school'
item.description: How one school in Croatia is working to improve education opportunities for Roma children like Kristina.

item.title: Extreme weather: What causes flash flooding?
item.description: Cities across the world are at risk of extreme rainfall overwhelming their streets

item.title: Covid passports: How do they work around the world?
item.description: How are countries enforcing vaccine passports and what can people use them for?

item.title: Tips from the Netherlands on how to build a nation of cyclists
item.description: Some tips from the Dutch Cycling Embassy on how to make bikes the easiest and safest way to travel.

item.title: I survived Norway's worst terror attack
item.description: Lisa Husby recalls hiding in fear as far-right extremist Anders Breivik went on a killing spree in 2011.

item.title: Europe floods: 'I have an axe beside my bed'
item.description: Marion Wenzel showed the BBC around her flood-wrecked house in Ahrweiler, Germany.

item.title: First space tourist Dennis Tito: 'I was euphoric'
item.description: Dennis Tito paid $20 million to travel to the International Space Station in 2001.

item.title: Horse racing: Inside the abattoir slaughtering racehorses
item.description: Campaign group Animal Aid set up covert cameras in one of the few slaughterhouses licensed to kill horses.
